title: Cufon and (c)
content:
Hi,

For fun I used this tool - [http://cufon.shoqolate.com/generate/](http://web.archive.org/web/20111209195915/http:/cufon.shoqolate.com/generate/ "http://cufon.shoqolate.com/generate/") to create a [Cufon](http://web.archive.org/web/20111209195915/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Cufon) format font. Upon opening the resulting .js file in a text editor I noticed that the font's (c) and trademark strings didn't come across. Anyone know if that's a limitation on the font format or if it's possible to paste in these strings?

Cheers, Si
author: Sii Daniels

comments.content:

Just the line of code you're referring to will suffice. The reason I'm asking is because I had a similar thing happen in reverse - the generator picked up something in the font name and substituted some unicode values that caused the file to malfunction. I had to remove it manually.

rich

Typically when you authorize someone to make a derivative font based on your IP, you require that your (c) string and perhaps more importantly your trademark notice appear in the derivative font. I’m somewhat surprised that font makers would license their fonts for conversion into the Cufon format if this information is stripped out.

What happens when a font is used via Flash?

Anyway, if required, a copyright notice can be added as a javascript comment easy enough.  
Multiline:  
/\*  
WonderFont by Sii 2009 All Rights Reserved  
 [http://wonderfont.org](http://web.archive.org/web/20111209195915/http:/wonderfont.org/ "http://wonderfont.org")  
\*/  
Single line:  
// WonderFont by Sii 2009 All Rights Reserved

Thanks!

\>What happens when a font is used via Flash?

My understanding is that today the entire font gets sucked in (c), TM and all. I don't know about the past. But that's more of an embedding scenario, not a file conversion / derivative font creation process.

There is a legal requirement that copyright statements be preserved. After I brought this up with Cufón developer Simo Kinnunen, he very kindly (and quickly!) released a new version of his generator to correct this problem.

(I haven't had time to confirm this, though.)

Great. Glad I rasied the subject. Will give it a try.

Cheers, Si

Finally, my memory jogged on this. The problem I had was with a trademark symbol which was actually in the name of the font. That's what I had to remove. Screwed whatever it was I trying to do up royally. But unrelated to your question, Sii.  
I'm just wondering if the copyright statement has been preserved in human (as in my javascript comment example) or in javascript form.

\* Â© 2009 Microsoft Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

What I have been told is that copyright is more legally important; the DMCA requires that it be preserved. Not so for trademark. (Apparently. IANAL.)

Simo and I discussed the choice of putting the copyright statement in JS comments versus the binary data. The former is more accessible, but could (in theory, I guess) get stripped by "some Javascript optimizers". So, while I speculated that it might be more bulletproof to embed the copyright in the binary, Simo chose to put it in text comments, and observed that any other software that chose to strip it would probably be violating the DMCA or some other law. Seems okay to me.
Oh, BTW, I did suggest to Simo that he query other foundries to see what kinds of legal/informational text would be desirable to preserve in Cufón.

Sii\>TM is more important than (c).

Since no fonts I've ever heard of have permission to convert to EOT with Cufon, any more than we license people to use font forge to make whatever modifications they want to our fonts, (and regardless of whether the font contains a correct (c) in the end), the (tm) is violated by either a rename, or a same-named file with different contents. <cite> > I mean, what do you think goes on when someone opens up one of FB’s fonts in Photoshop and a minute later there’s a gif based on it posted on a web site somewhere?</cite>

With all due respect, Rich, that's a different case.

In your Photoshop example, the font data has been utilized (not "opened up" btw), as provided, to perform as it was licensed to do: to render letterforms. The user is then free to do as he wishes with the fixed, rendered form; just like printing.

In the "Cufón" example (I'm using this as representative, not to pick on Cufón specifically), the font data itself is being materially modified to perform differently. Such a modification of the software data itself is a derivation under copyright and one needs permission from the intellectual property owner to do so.

Currently, the general license of most foundries does not grant this permission off-the-shelf. So, developers need to ask first. Some foundries may grant that permission, some may not. That's their right. Some may want additional fees, some may not. That's also their right.

If you can't come to terms, then you'll take your business elsewhere. I realize you hate having to jump through that hoop. The technologies and markets are still emerging. It will take a while to sort out.

There may come a day when the permission to make these modifications becomes incorporated as a de facto part of a standard license. I get that that's what you'd like to see happen. But we aren't there yet.

But there's always going to be someone who does it anyway, and the "EULA allows this" checkbox is pretty much all we can do about it. In cases like this, would you rather not have your copyright embedded to the font files at all?

What do you count as modification anyway? Even Abode Flash slightly modifies the curves of embedded fonts by converting them to quadratic ones (see "Converting TrueType fonts to SWF glyphs", page 172 of [http://www.adobe.com/devnet/swf/pdf/swf\_file\_format\_spec\_v10.pdf](http://web.archive.org/web/20111209195915/http:/www.adobe.com/devnet/swf/pdf/swf_file_format_spec_v10.pdf "http://www.adobe.com/devnet/swf/pdf/swf\_file\_format\_spec\_v10.pdf")). Now, Cufón obviously takes things a bit further by allowing the user to scale the font down and optimize the path after that for the purpose of decreasing file size, but this functionality can be turned off. After that it's not much different from what Flash does. The curves are just converted to cubic beziers and stored in VML format.

From the SWF spec:

"The complete procedure for converting TrueType glyphs to SWF glyphs is as follows:

1. Negate the y-coordinate. (In TrueType glyphs, the y-axis points up; in SWF glyphs, the y- axis points down.)
2. Scale the x and y co-ordinates from the EM square of the TrueType font, to the EM square of the SWF glyph (always 1024).
3. Insert an on-curve (anchor) point at the midpoint of each pair of off-curve points."

So actually Flash scales things too. Both Cufón and Flash do 1. They both also do 2, although this can be turned off in Cufón. The 3rd point is different but the purpose is the same. So, they're not that much different after all.

It would be interesting to find out whether PDFs also do something like this.

Rich -- I am always reluctant to debate the details of copyright in these forums, because it's a rabbit hole and because we aren't lawyers. But heck, I suppose in a way I started this. And exploring these concepts in an open, constructive conversation can be instructive. I feel like you and I can probably have such a discussion.

I will need some time to consider your questions and compose a measure response. But I wanted you to know that I am taking you seriously.

Rich, re. fair use:

_What fair use rights do I have with regards to font files? By law I have to have some regardless of what any EULA might say and I was just wondering what you thought those might be._

In US law, as I understand it, fair use rights are determined by a balancing test, which is a judicial process. So rather than the usual disclaimer that I'm not a lawyer, in this case I should point out that I'm not a jurist.

With explicit judicial ruling regarding fair use of font files, you have to look at fair use for similar copyright material. Since fonts are copyrighted as software, the most obvious place to start looking is fair use of copyrighted and commercially licensed software. Now, a lot of software licenses explicitly forbid decompiling the software, which applied to fonts would prevent font format conversions or any tinkering inside the font as a font; even opening such a font in FontLab to take a look at it would constitute license infringement. Frankly, I would be surprised if you could make a case that decompiling software is fair use if the license disallows it, even if you do not do anything more with the software, but I'm not aware of case law relating to this.

If we presume a font license does not explicitly disallow decompiling the font binary, what fair use rights might exist? Given that distributing a derivative work is contrary to the whole purpose of copyright, I doubt if any balancing test would permit that. So the question is probably whether you have a fair use right to modify the font for your own purposes, and to use the resulting derivative work but not to distribute it or use it beyond the scope of the original license. There are, of course, plenty of font licenses that explicitly _permit_ such modification of fonts; but there are others that explicitly disallow it, that require you to go back to the font maker if you want a custom version even for your own use. So I read your question as 'Are such license prohibitions enforceable, or is that a fair use right to modify fonts?' Again, you'd have to look at the general state of software copyright first, and then more specific case law and, for a final decision, get a judicial balancing test decision on fonts per se.

Since John has already taken his stab at question no. 1, let me stay on just that topic.

I will state that I am not a lawyer (even if I begin to sound like one) and none of my comments should be construed as legal advice. Also, I am not offering any official interpretation of licenses for any foundries that I might work with. I am just giving my personal opinions.

I will assume, as John has, that for the sake of this discussion we are talking about the U.S. Copyright Law, which is contained in Title 17 of the United States Code.

Anyone is welcome to read it for themselves. The full text of the law can be found here: [http://www.copyright.gov/title17/index.html](http://web.archive.org/web/20111209195915/http:/www.copyright.gov/title17/index.html "http://www.copyright.gov/title17/index.html") and can be downloaded as Circular 92.

The doctrine of "fair use" is outlined in §107 -- Limitations on Exclusive Rights: Fair Use. It gives the principles for possible exceptions to the rights stated in §106.

So, before we delve into fair use let's just review that §106 of the Copyright Code secures to the owner of copyright the exclusive right to do (and to authorize others to do) a couple different things: [I'm paraphrasing here]

(1) Reproduce the work in copies;  
(2) Prepare derivative works based upon the copyrighted work;  
(3) Distribute copies of the work by sale or other transfer of ownership, or by rental, lease, or lending;  
(plus a few others that pertain only to other media, primarily visual and performing arts, so I'm not going to enumerate them here).

§107 then outlines a "fair use exception" to the exclusivity of those rights "for purposes such as criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching, scholarship, or research."

John is right that the Fair Use Exception is usually an affirmative defense against claims of infringement. It would be up case law to determine what uses would actually constitute fair use. Since the statutes were written primarily from the perspective of visual art, written works, and musical works, it's a little hard to say where things would come down in relation to font software.

I will go out on a limb and give my opinion -- contrary to the opinion John expressed above -- that despite most EULAs' prohibition against "decompiling, reverse engineering, and disassembling" you could probably make a case under Fair Use for a right to open up a font and examine the outlines purely for the purposes of learning and research.

I'm not sure what application the doctrine of fair use might have in the specific case of Cufón here. But if you see an argument, feel free to posit it.

Keep in mind, the statute gives four factors to be used in the consideration of whether a particular case is fair use or not: [I'm quoting in full this time]

(1) the purpose and character of the use, including whether such use is of a commercial nature or is for nonprofit educational purposes;  
(2) the nature of the copyrighted work;  
(3) the amount and substantiality of the portion used in relation to the copyrighted work as a whole; and  
(4) the effect of the use upon the potential market for or value of the copyrighted work.

This is the balancing test that John referred to.

Kent: _...you could probably make a case under Fair Use for a right to open up a font and examine the outlines purely for the purposes of learning and research._

This would depend, I think, on factors 1 and 4 of the balancing test, i.e. what are you intending to do with the knowledge you gain from studying the decompiled font software. The common prohibition against decompiling software is that you will be able to see how it is made and this will give you an unfair advantage in producing a competing product (in that you will not have invested in the original creative development).
